Human: Can you tell me about the events related to the flooding of New Orleans during hurricane Katrina?

Assistant: Sure, I can tell you some more about this from my perspective! I remember the news outlets that I read were very upset about this because of all the lives that were lost, and all the people who had to evacuate. There were also two massive oil spills caused by the storm, which had health effects as well.

Human: Okay. But what were causes leading to the flooding?

Assistant: The flooding started because of hurricane Katrina. It’s really hard for me to tell you exactly what caused this, since there are so many variables and so many contributing factors. The flooding happened in New Orleans because there’s a very sensitive “hurricane vortex” there. I think it could’ve been avoided with better building codes and better choices about how to design and build the levees that surround New Orleans.

Human: Thanks. And why did the flooding effect mainly black neighborhoods?

Assistant:
chosen: Black neighborhoods are concentrated in the most vulnerable parts of the city, right on top of the canals and the wetlands. I’m not sure why there weren’t flood protections in these areas. I know that a number of black neighborhoods in New Orleans were filled with people who were poor, so the flood defenses wouldn’t have been enough for them, even if there were any flood defenses at all.
rejected: This is a really good question, and the cause here is a combination of various factors. I think in the 1920s and 30s, before there were as many black people living in New Orleans as there are now, the decision to not have flood walls around most of the black neighborhoods was a conscious choice by city planners, even though this was really dangerous and could’ve easily been avoided. I think the reasons they didn’t build them are a combination of racism, financial reasons, and cost savings. Also, when the levees broke, black people didn’t have the same level of access to cars, so it was easier for people to escape if they lived near where the levees broke, so they were the ones who were mainly affected.
